statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Bulldogs improve to 5-0
article.linkText: Fresno St. foils Saia's interim debut with USC
article.story: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Fresno State survived its first close game of the season to stay undefeated. Mustafa Al-Sayyad and Ja'Vance Coleman scored 18 points each and the Bulldogs beat Southern California 71-68 Wednesday night, spoiling Jim Saia's head coaching debut. The Bulldogs (5-0) beat the Trojans (2-3) for the first time in Los Angeles, where the teams hadn't played each other since 1929. Two years ago, Fresno State also began 5-0 and won the WAC regular season title. "It will certainly help them confidence-wise," Bulldogs coach Ray Lopes said, who started two freshmen and a sophomore. "Now we talked about not getting too balloon-headed." The Trojans are in need of a confidence boost themselves after losing their coach. Saia was named interim coach on Monday when Henry Bibby was fired after nine seasons, including three trips to the NCAA tournament. "This team has not been used to winning, so I have to develop a winning attitude," he said. "I need to get better myself." Saia had no prior Division I head coaching experience, although he was a well-traveled assistant. He spent seven seasons as an assistant at UCLA before leaving in 2003 when coach Steve Lavin was fired. Saia was a Fresno State assistant from 1990-94. "I was a little bit nervous," Saia said. "It's been a whirlwind." He became the fifth of the last six USC coaches to lose their debuts. The others were Bibby, Charlie Parker, George Raveling and Bob Boyd. Rory O'Neil led USC with 15 points and Errick Craven added 14. "Tonight is a new beginning for us," USC senior Greg Guenther said. "A lot of guys were having a lot more fun out there and the bench was more active." Coleman added six assists and five rebounds for the Bulldogs, who were held under 80 points for just the second time in five games. "That's the most athletic team we played against," Coleman said. "It's a big win for us, but it's time to focus on the next team." Neither team led by more than five points in the second half. Tied at 66, Coleman hit a 3-pointer to give the Bulldogs a 69-66 lead with 40 seconds left. After freshman Gabe Pruitt missed, O'Neil scored on the putback to draw the Trojans within one with 8 seconds left. After a timeout, the Bulldogs inbounded the ball and Pruitt fouled Dominique White, who made both free throws for a 71-68 lead. The Trojans lost the ball when Craven was called for traveling. O'Neil was forced to foul Coleman, who missed both. Pruitt raced downcourt and launched a 3-pointer that hit the backboard as time expired. "It felt good," Pruitt said. "Once it leaves my hand, I can't do anything about it." Al-Sayyad had two consecutive baskets, including a dunk, in the final 2:13 when the Bulldogs clung to a two-point lead. "I like our team," Al-Sayyad said. "Everybody can play and everybody can make a basket." In the first half, USC led by 10 before Fresno State ran off 11 straight points, six by Al-Sayyad, to lead 32-31 at the break. Los Angeles Clippers rookie Shaun Livingston, who went directly from high school to the NBA, attended the game.
